petitioner.name: ATLANTIC SOUNDING CO., INC., ET AL.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument next in Case 08-214, Atlantic Sounding v. Townsend. Mr. McCreadie.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. McCreadie, in this case, why is it necessary to get into that, whether they are punitive damages under FELA and the Jones Act? If we accept, as I think we must, Townsend's allegations to be true, he has said that Atlantic, as a matter of routine, puts in a boilerplate complaint for declaratory relief, reciting all the reasons why somebody could not get maintenance and cure, even though that is patently false, the allegation for example that he deserted his post. He says it's false. He said the allegation that he falsified his application for employment is false. Accepting the -- that to be true at this stage, isn't there some kind of punitive measure to be taken against a litigant who abuses the court process in that way?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Yes, but -- but now we're at the pretrial stage, and we're supposed to assume the truth of the allegations in Townsend's complaint. We're assuming -- they may well turn out to be false; but at the threshold under 12(b)6 we accept those allegations as true and then determine whether a claim is stated.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But let's take this out of the maintenance and cure spot altogether. Litigation generally, if a court determines that a litigant is abusing the court's process by filing false pleadings, is there a remedy; and if so, what is it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I thought that all that was at stake there was whether the employer wrongfully withheld maintenance and cure that was owing. The allegations made by Townsend go far beyond that they just unreasonably denied him maintenance and cure. They suggest that this litigant, as a matter practice, standard operating procedure, makes false claims before a court. And my question to you is, isn't across the board there a sanction, wholly apart from the particular claim, for a litigant who abuses the court's processes?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is any of them called punitive damages? Do you know of any case in which a court has - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And punitive damages, of course, requires that you first find the guilty person to lose the case. So what if a person makes these terrible allegations, but ends up winning the case anyway, and -- and -- well, you couldn't impose punitive damages.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: We've got to call it something else, don't we?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: How many - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But do you read Vaughan v. Atkinson as necessarily implying punitive damages would be inappropriate? I can't quite find the negative that you want me to find, I think, in Atkinson. True, they didn't talk about punitive damages. They said damages are appropriate, and attorneys' fees in this case, which is what the district court gave, we are going to affirm it. But there's nothing there that said punitive damages are inappropriate.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Whose dissent was that? I have forgotten that. Whose dissent was it? Do you recall? Stewart?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: You said never in the history. I mean, there -- there are examples like the ancient Nancy case, where the damages, where they were called exemplary -- but when you say never has there been before or after punitive awards. But there is precedent, the Nancy case in this Court, cases in lower courts, there have been punitive damages awards in -- in maintenance and cure cases.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Did this Court ever hold that under FELA or under the Jones Act there are no punitive damages? Do we have any holding to that effect?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But that -- but that was a common law wrongful death action, correct, Miles?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: It was not admiralty maintenance and cure.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Excuse me, that the maintenance and cure claim could proceed or that the punitive damages claim could be made?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. McCreadie, there's a question about this case, a troublesome feature of it. That is, you are saying because there are no punitive damages available under FELA and under the Jones Act, then there certainly should not be any under maintenance and cure. But if we have to answer those questions, whether there are punitive damages available under FELA and the Jones Act, in the context of a maintenance and cure claim, then we're deciding a much larger question than are punitive damages available for willful refusal to pay maintenance and cure. We're deciding a question under the Jones Act, a question under the FELA, and there are a lot of people who would be interested -- and the seamen are a sizable group that the law cares about particularly. But there would be a larger interest, a larger interest in the answer in the Jones Act context and FELA. And to decide those questions in a case that doesn't present any claim under FELA or any claim under the Jones Act is troublesome.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: As I read your reply brief -- and please correct me if it's a misimpression -- you didn't dispute the fact that punitive damages were available historically for the shipowner's wrongful refusal to provide maintenance and cure, or am I wrong about that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And what about English admiralty, under the English precedents?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Of course, in Miles - - again, we're coming back -- was wrongful death, not maintenance and cure.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Of course, your friend on the other side distinguishes that argument by noting that death is different. As he puts it, we're all going to die, so - -

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- you have different considerations under the maintenance and cure.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I thought there was -- it was on the high seas. They had DOHSA. At the time of Moragne, there was DOHSA, but then it was when you weren't on the high seas that was the gap. Wasn't that the case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But that's what the common law was. That's why we had Lord Campbell's Act. That was if you die, too bad; if you're injured, you collect. That was fixed by statute on the high seas, DOHSA. Because there was the gap, there was no Lord Campbell's Act, the Court effectively made one up, right? That's what it did in Moragne.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But I just -- and you can go ahead and answer that question without my interrupting. But my assumption from reading the amicus briefs in this case is that punitive damages were awarded in some maintenance and cure cases (a) as simply part of the overall award -- they weren't separated out, but it was part of the measure -- and (b) that some American courts, American judges, including noted admiralty judges, awarded in some cases punitive damages in maintenance and cure before the modern cases Moragne and so forth -- and Miles -- that you're talking about. Is that incorrect?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I'm talking pre-Miles. I'm talking pre-Miles.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is -- how many -- how many would you say there are in a typical year, maintenance and cure cases? About, roughly? I mean, say in the late twentieth century, 18 -- 1980, 1990. Have you have any guess at all?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So how many would you guess?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Uh-huh. And they usually have maintenance and cure aspects.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Can you get punitives under the Jones Act or not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What about unseaworthiness?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay, so if I have about 30 cases -- no, I had, actually, to be honest, I thought we found about 12 in the period around 1980 - 2000 where they do give some punitive damages.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right. Then I found about 10 cases in the period before the Jones Act where there was something given -- punitive damages being given for something, and there was something sort of like maintenance and cure in there.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Over here, there is one called -- Unica v U.S. The master should have put the -- into the hospital. Given him $1,500. It was partly punitive. Considering -- De Troupe -- I mean, I found some that are sort of -- sort of -- I don't know what to say. I don't know who to make of it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: The Troop gave them $4,000. Considering all the circumstances of the aggravation. Gross neglect, mistreatment. "It is useless to parade more of the sickening details."

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Sullivan.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, surely there will be some incidents in which the employer in good faith thinks there's no illness, that there's no basis for maintenance and cure.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: For you to tell me oh, this will just never happen, I mean, that's not the way the world works.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, of course there are going to be disputes, and the question is whether or not, just from the standpoint of filling professional responsibility, in almost any maintenance and cure action where the counsel for the plaintiff thinks that -- for the seaman thinks that the employer has been remiss, he doesn't add the punitive damages complaint if we agree with your position, which changes completely the settlement and the bargaining aspect. But you can address -- you can address that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: How many of these seamen who seek maintenance and cure are represented? I mean, what is the incidence of representation for maintenance and cure claims as distinguished from Jones Act negligence type claims with the -- the possibility of large recoveries for pain and suffering?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, why -- why does joining it to a Jones Act case help?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, the -- the point you are making is that the recovery under the Jones Act can be very large, and the attorney on a contingent basis would get a piece of that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Because it would be swelled by the pain and suffering damages which are not available in maintenance and cure.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What is the pre-Vaughan case that awarded punitive damages - - awarded punitive damages in a maintenance and cure case?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I am -- what - - which --any case from this Court?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: All right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: It hasn't come before this Court under FELA or the Jones Act, either, the punitive damage question?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Rolf was not a -- Rolf was maintenance and cure and personal injury and unseaworthiness. So we don't know which aspect of the case led to the punitives.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is it the case that we can't find a single pre-Jones Act case where punitives were awarded and what was sought was maintenance and cure? I -- I found some, but they seem ambiguous to me.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What is your best?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So we have a history all the way back to Catherine of Aragon, and what we've been able to find in these pre-Jones Act cases is really two or three, or maybe I found ten actually, that I couldn't say -- leaning over in your direction, I could take maybe three or four. And they show a little ambiguity. But give them all ten, and that's still ten out of hundreds of years of history.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: If I thought that the lack of counsel in maintenance and cure cases was a pivotal point or a relevant point for our decision, other than the representations of counsel, where would I look to verify that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: The -- the -- that there is a problem in seamen finding attorneys who will take maintenance and cure cases.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, if -- if the -- if the existence of the punitive damages and maintenance and cure were as well established, why wasn't that mentioned in terms in the Vaughan majority? It only comes up in the Vaughan dissent.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Do you think Stewart knew more about these -- these obscure, ancient cases than we do?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Do you think he knew more about these obscure, ancient cases than we do?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Had he had the benefit of briefs by Professor Robertson and -- I think not, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It was just sort of off the top of his head that he thought there should be punitive damages.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: They -- they normally are, but the question is whether there -- whether this - - this is a different quiver.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And that -- that was not argued by anybody. It wasn't raised in the lower court. It wasn't a punitive damages case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: With attorneys' fees there is a compensatory aspect. The -- the basic obligation is to keep this seaman alive and well, and then you give him some wages if necessary, and you give him medical care. And -- and now he's going to be out that attorneys' fees as a result of his sickness. So I understand that. Punitives does not compensate him for anything. It is a policy matter for the State. He's a beneficiary of a windfall. And it seems a more radical step to make something up out of whole cloth here with punitives than it does with attorneys' fees.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Maybe it would be a good thing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: The -- the problem here is it has pros and cons. I was quite moved by the brief - - the citation that Professor Robertson made of all of those old cases until we looked them up. And -- and then I found they seem to stand for a little bit less than I had the impression they stood for.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So we'd be making this up out of whole cloth, it seems to me.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: We've abandoned that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- because Miles says don't do that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Exactly. We've abandoned that in this hearing. We said what we do with these admiralty causes of action we should be guided by what Congress has done in the Death on the High Seas Act and the Jones Act. Do you acknowledge that there are no punitive damages available in the event of death?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, that -- you want to talk about what's a sensible system and what is not a sensible system. In the days when Massachusetts used to have a -- when I was in law school, they had a compensation limit for wrongful death, but to limit for pain and suffering, for negligence; and the line was back her up again -- back her up again, Sam, she's not quite dead yet. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is -- is -- is this going to be the same thing, where -- where the ship owner says, well, you know, if -- if -- if I treat him badly enough that he dies, I don't get hit with the punitive damages?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yeah, but it is invited, isn't it?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm not sure as sure -- I'm not sure I follow that. In other areas where we allow punitive damages it hasn't resulted in the cases going away. Quite the opposite. It seems that it has given rise to a variety of claims on both sides.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Yeah, but the normal medical malpractice area has given rise to a lot of punitive damage litigation. I don't know why this would anybody different.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It certainly makes these maintenance and care cases a lot more attractive to the plaintiffs' bar doesn't it? I mean, one of your complaints is there's just no money in it. The claim is not for that much.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Of course it shouldn't be the goal. But we're inquiring into the question of whether granting punitive damages will increase or decrease the number of lawsuits. I -- I -- I would think it would be astounding if it would decrease the number of lawsuits.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: There -- there wouldn't be any maintenance and cure claim if the system worked as it was intended; that is, that if you have a sailor who is injured, the ship owner pays room and board and medical expenses.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I wish it were as clearcut as that. I mean, what if the seaman says, you know, I should have had this very expensive treatment? And the ship owner's medical counsel said, no, this treatment is not necessary. Is that -- is that a punitive damages claim? I bet it is.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: He's going to say that was willful and wanton. I obviously needed this more expensive treatment. He just didn't want to pay the money.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, I mean, it - - whether it gives rise to more litigation or not, it is still a significant and will give rise to greater costs on the part of the shipper which will be passed on, as is the case in a lot of areas where you have punitive damages, it will be passed on to the consumer.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: No, no, even if they're not. In other words, you were saying, look, to avoid punitive damages, the ship owner is going to make sure that there -- that that more expensive test is provided.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: That doesn't mean there are no costs involved in ruling in your favor.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Mr. McCreadie, you have three minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Is that a separate cause of action? Or is it just part of the maintenance and cure act?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Are you -- are you then disputing what your colleague said about lawyers being reluctant to take maintenance and cure claims that are not tied with a Jones Act claim?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
